+
By far the most common way to approach applied ethics is by resolving individual cases. This is, not coincidentally, also the way [[business]] and [[law]] tend to be taught. ''[[Casuistry]]'' is one such application of [[case-based reasoning]] to applied ethics. Almost all American states have tried to discourage dishonest practices by their employees by establishing an Ethics Commission for their state.
  +      
[[Bernard Crick]] in [[1982]] offered a more socially-centered view, that [[politics]] was the only applied ethics, that it was how cases were really resolved, and that "[[political virtues]]" were in fact necessary in all matters where human morality and interests were destined to clash. This and other views of modern universals is dealt with below under ''Global Ethics''.
